A: Customers should consider using A1 instances for scale-out workloads that can fit within the available memory footprint and have minimal to no x86 dependencies. A1 instances are ideal for applications based on interpreted or run-time compiled languages and offer significant cost savings. On the other hand, M6g instances may be a better choice for memory-intensive workloads or applications that require high CPU performance, as they provide up to 40% more CPU power compared to A1 instances.

Q: What are the key differences between AWS Graviton and x86 processors?
A: AWS Graviton processors are based on the 64-bit Arm instruction set and feature Arm Neoverse cores as well as custom silicon designed by AWS. They operate at a frequency of 2.3 GHz. In contrast, x86 processors are based on different instruction sets and designs, and their performance and power efficiency may vary.
